rename.from: Next.js build fails with vanilla-extract and edge runtime
rename.to: Build fails with vanilla-extract and edge runtime

body: @miktirr Can you clarify why you need to use Edge Runtime in Layouts?

@samcx We use Edge Runtime for the whole application (our deploy target is edge network). Having the [runtime definition](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/file-conventions/route-segment-config#runtime) in a low level layout has been economical as it has set the runtime for all the pages.

I think the [documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/file-conventions/route-segment-config#runtime) needs to be updated.

The sentence states Middleware is the only supported option for this, but then it lists the different files you can use it in.

> We recommend using the Node.js runtime for rendering your application

There shouldn't be a difference in performance if you just use the default runtime (Node.js) for your Layouts and Pages.

I’m not sure I follow. Next.js has [two server runtimes](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/rendering/edge-and-nodejs-runtimes) for applications, right? The Edge Runtime is just the default (and until recently the only) option for Middleware.

We deploy our app to edge network where Node.js and Node.js APIs are not available. This is why we use Edge Runtime not only for the Middleware but for the whole app.

> We deploy our app to edge network where Node.js and Node.js APIs are not available.

Is it possible to clarify with edge network you are referring to?
We currently use Cloudflare’s edge network.

Is there information we could provide to help resolving the problem? This is currently preventing us from updating past the version 15.1.7. I checked that the problem exists still in v15.3.0-canary.20. Moving the edge runtime declaration from the layout to the page doesn’t change the situation. For production build it is possible to circumvent the problem by building twice (the first build fails but seconds succeeds). But the error also happens with the dev mode:

issue.title: bugfix: Fix a bug that caused conflicting assets when adding a child compiler
issue.body:
fixes #76930

## Summary

Fixes an issue where using a Webpack plugin that creates child compilers in a Next.js project could result in asset emission conflicts.

## Description

Starting from [vercel/next.js#75927](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/75927), Next.js uses compilation.emitAsset to emit assets. However, emitAsset throws an error when attempting to emit an asset with the same name and identical content more than once.
This behavior is defined in Webpack's implementation:
https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/70e3d9d5dbd3548431b8878dead4647beff5c14f/lib/Compilation.js#L4615-L4628

When a plugin hooks into the compilation phase, it also runs for child compilers. This can lead to duplicated asset emission when using plugins that spawn child compilers, such as [vanilla-extract](https://github.com/vanilla-extract-css/vanilla-extract/blob/c66be53d600802b2922da1d6034e2a5ff3fbbcae/packages/webpack-plugin/src/compiler.ts#L85-L89).

To prevent this, we now use the thisCompilation hook instead of compilation, which ensures that the plugin only applies to the main compilation and not to any child compilers.

body:
Hi @samcx,
This issue is not related to whether EdgeRuntime is used or not.
The root cause is a change made to the Webpack plugin in the following PR:
https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/75927
I’ve created a PR to fix the issue. Could you take a look?
https://github.com/vercel/next.js/pull/78011

Hi @samcx,
It's been about two weeks since I opened the PR, and I haven't heard anything back. Is there anything I can do on my end?

@Karibash I've pinged the team to take a look.

If we don't hear anything soon, let me know and I'll circle back!
@samcx Any updates on this? At least on the public front it’s been quiet for a couple of weeks.
